fields.title: Home
fields.content:
Welcome to HIERTAGS, a site dedicated to tag hierarchy extraction.

Tags appear rather frequently on various on line platforms like blogs, photo sharing portals, news feeds, etc. In most cases they correspond to free words, chosen by independent people, thus, the resulting organization of the tags is "flat", (all tags are equal), opposed to traditional hierarchical categorization. Nevertheless, the way users think about the tagged objects has some built in hierarchy, e.g., "poodle" is usually considered as a special case of "dog". An interesting challenge related to this problem is the extraction of this sort of hierarchy between the tags based on statistical properties as tag frequencies, co-occurrences, etc.

On this site we provide algorithms extracting a tag hierarchy from the weighted co-occurrence network between the tags, (where the weight of a link corresponds to the number of shared objects). Furthermore, we also offer tagged datasets for testing tag hierarchy extracting algorithms in general.

fields.title: Archive
fields.content:
Download older versions of the tag-hierarchy extracting algorithms:

Both algorithms are aimed at extracting a directed acyclic graph (a hierarchy) between tags from co-occurrence statistics. A detailed description of the algorithms can be found in our paper "Extracting tag hierarchies". They take either the weighted co-occurrence network between the tags as the input, (accompanied by the frequency distribution of the tags), or simply the list of co-occurring tags on the individual objects, (in which case the first step is the preparation of the co-occurrence network). The output is simply the list of directed links between the tags, representing the hierarchy. Both algorithms are implemented in Perl.

Version used in the publication PLoS ONE 8(12): e84133.)
Download Algorithm A (reconstr_A_1.0.pl, perl, 14Kb, 2013.11.01.)
Download Algorithm B (reconstr_B_1.0.pl, perl, 11Kb, 2013.11.01.)

last version and example datasets are here

fields.title: Downloads
fields.content:
Download our tag-hierarchy extracting algorithms:

Both algorithms are aimed at extracting a directed acyclic graph (a hierarchy) between tags from co-occurrence statistics. A detailed description of the algorithms can be found in our paper "Extracting tag hierarchies". They take either the weighted co-occurrence network between the tags as the input, (accompanied by the frequency distribution of the tags), or simply the list of co-occurring tags on the individual objects, (in which case the first step is the preparation of the co-occurrence network). The output is simply the list of directed links between the tags, representing the hierarchy. Both algorithms are implemented in Perl.
Download Algorithm A (reconstr_A.pl, perl, 14Kb, updated 2014.01.16.)
Download Algorithm B (reconstr_B.pl, perl, 11Kb, updated 2014.01.16.)

archived versions are here

Download our tagged datasets:

Protein dataset:
A collection of proteins tagged by their known function annotations, describing molecular functions. The original dataset was taken from the Gene Ontology, providing both a hierarchy between the molecular functions and also a quality controlled list of known function annotations for the proteins. We narrowed the list of molecular functions to be taken into account to the descendants of "catalytic" activity" in the hierarchy. Thus, our dataset is limited to proteins having at least one annotation from the descendants of "catalytic activity", and any tag coming from other parts of the hierarchy is excluded from the lists of annotations.
List of proteins: compressed plain text file, where each row corresponds to a protein,
1st. column: protein id, rest of the columns: function ids.
Download (List_of_proteins.zip: 31Mb, extracted size: 138Mb)
Tag hierarchy: plain text file giving the directed acyclic graph between,
the tags, 1st column: source id, 2nd column: target id.
Download (Protein_tag_hierarchy.txt, 52kB)
Function names: compressed plain text file giving the names of the molecular functions,
1st column: function id, rest of the columns: the name
Download (Protein_function_names.zip, 356kB, extracted size: 1.8Mb)
Download all files in the protein dataset as a zip archive. (Protein_dataset.zip, 32Mb)

Flickr dataset:
We provide a weighted co-occurrence network between Flickr tags together with the corresponding tag frequencies. This network is resulting from the tags (free words) co-appearing on photos in rather long list of queries from Flickr. In the preparation of the network we kept only English nouns and took into account co-occurrences only if they were present on photos from at least 10 different users. (More details on the data are given in our manuscript "Extracting tag hierarchies").
Co-occurrence network: compressed plain text file with 3 columns,
1st. and 2nd. columns: co-appearing tag ids,
3d. column: number of co-occurrences
Download (Flickr_co-occurrence_net.zip, 5.5Mb, extracted size: 18Mb)
Tag frequencies: compressed plain text file with 2 columns,
1st. column: tag id, 2nd column: number of photos
Download (Flickr_tag_frequencies.zip, 101Kb, extracted size: 247kb)
Tag names: compressed plain text file with 2 columns,
1st. colum: tag id, 2nd column: name
Download (Flickr_tag_names.zip, 1.3Mb, extracted size: 2.7Mb)
Download all files in the Flickr dataset as a zip archive. (Flickr_dataset.zip, 6.9Mb)

Sort example from the Flickr database: plain text file, where each row corresponds to a photo. Note: the tag frequency distribution in this data is different as in the large Flickr dataset, hence the reconstructed tag-hierarchy is different as well
1st column: photo id, rest of columns: keywords
Download (flickr_example_300_annots.txt: 1.4Mb)

IMDb dataset:
A filtered data set listing most frequent keywords associated with movies in the IMDb. We kept keywords appearing at least on 100 different movies in the original data , downloaded from here .
List of movies: compressed plain text file, where each row corresponds to a movie,
1st. column: movie title id, rest of the columns: keyword ids.
Download (List_of_movies.zip, 9.9Mb, extracted size: 25Mb)
Tag id names: compressed plain text file with 2 columns,
1st. colum: tag id, 2nd column: name
Download (Movie_keyword_names.zip, 1.2Mb, extracted size: 3Mb)
Download all files in the Imdb dataset as a zip archive.
(imdb_dataset.zip, 6.3Mb )

Copyrigth notice: Information courtesy of
IMDb
( www.imdb.com ).
For further information contact: licensing@imdb.com
Short dataset for testing:
A very short dataset, constructed for testing the code and getting results in a few seconds.

List of objects with tags for testing: plain text file, where each row corresponds to an object with tags. For simplicity each object and tag is represented by a number.
1st. colum: object, 2nd and further columns: tags
Download (777b)
List of objects for testing in weighted network format: Two plain text files: one file for the co-occurrence network between tags, the other file is for the corresponding tag frequencies. For simplicity each object and tag is represented by a number.
Co-occurrence network 1st and 2nd columns: co-appearing tag ids
3d. column: number of co-occurrences
Download (621b)
Tag frequencies: compressed plain text file with 2 columns,
1st. column: tag id, 2nd column: number of tags
Download (619b)
Result for the testing dataset (both for tag-object and co-occurrence format) from Algorithm A:
Directed graph, where 1st. column: source , 2nd column: target
Download (16b)
Result for the testing dataset (both for tag-object and co-occurrence format) from Algorithm B:
Directed graph, where 1st. colum: source , 2nd column: target
Download (16b)

fields.title: File Upload Examples
fields.content:
The following file-formats are accepted by the system:

  • Edge list in one text file (.txt)
  • Zipped text files (.zip)
  • XGMML files (generated by Cytoscape) (.xgmml)
  • Cytoscape session files(both 2.x and 3.x) (.cys)


Edge list contains lines with node names separated by space to define an edge between them. Lines starting with '#' considered as comments.

The zip file must contain two text files named edges.txt and nodes.txt. In the edges file each row defines one edge in the graph, the source and target IDs are separated by space. In the nodes file each line defines one node, ID and name are separated by space (be careful not use spaces in the name part).

XGMML files are xml based graph files, usually exported by Cytoscape.

Cytoscape session files are session files used by Cytoscape.

The uploaded files can contain multiple graphs. The application selects the first, but you can change between them later. Only graphs with no loops can be used at the moment(which can be represented as a DAG(Directed Acyclic Graph)).

Nodes with no child element appears as blank circles, and nodes which has further child elements appears as filled circles. Left-clicking on a node opens its child elements, right-clicking opens all the child elements of the node(if graph has no more than 100 node) or opens until grandchilds(if graph has more than 100 nodes).

Here is a list of example files that can be uploaded directly:

  • example.txt
  • example.zip
  • example.xgmml
  • Cytoscape 2.8 session example
  • Cytoscape 3.0 session example

back to visualization

fields.content:

PLoS ONE 8(12): e84133. 8(12) e84133 (2013).
doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0084133

fields.title: Visualize
fields.content:
On this site you can visualize the result of the algorithm. After running the perl program on your computer, please upload the result file. Click on the Choose file button and select the file, then Submit the form. The system checks the file format of the network. Because the technical limitations of browser based network visualization, please do not use large networks. The network is rendered as SVG image, which is most effectively displayed in Google Chrome.

You can find example files and detailed description here
